job_title: Annonymus Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits are decent and you get a good amount of PTO
cons: The place is a dysfunctional mess. More people are leaving than joining the past several months. A lot of ol’ timers here who are just trying to coast by to retirement. Physicians here are extremely rude (extremely) and will gladly walk over you and make you feel like you’re their slave. And don’t you dare offer your advice or you’ll put a target on your back. Do yourself a favor senoritas and don’t work here!

The Director didn't like it when I said that the team was too small and the pay was too low, and I never recovered from that, so I left.

review_title: Focus only on faculty and new facilities
job_title: N|A in San Antonio, TX
pros: Fairly well organized (depending on department and dept leadership).
cons: Where to start? I've worked in this institution in different departments for a long time, and in some departments the dept. Chair has behaved appallingly and often the Manager who worked under him or her was just as bad. There is so much favoritism and nobody does anything about it. If you go to HR, their only role is to limit any damage to the institution and so they don't help. The people who to go to HR tend to come off worse (don't go to HR whatever you do). All the president and top personnel care about is that they build more and more clinics and hospitals, not paying their staff reasonable salaries. They keep salaries as close to the minimum as possible and have stopped merit because - you guess it - they are building a new hospital and that's where all the money is going. They don't care about staff at all. Only faculty and that they build a bigger and bigger name.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Salary is decent for current cost of living, but all depends on supervisor’s support, and how well your relationship is with them. Salary is better than UTSA who expect more work than pay. After comparison with other admins, I think UTHSCSA can do better, compared to cost of living, I’m okay.
cons:
Campus is boring. A lot of the faculty and researchers are cold, don’t smile, rarely exchange a greeting. Students are the same; almost always on their phone facing down. Not very good selection of restaurants around, so you’re better staying put in your office and eating there. If you’re close to your car, you may have enough time to really out and make a quick trip to Target. Again this depends on your supervisor.
Also, if you make a lateral move, EVEN AFTER LEARNING NEW THINGS, you’re salary will stay the same. So if you move as an admin sr. to a larger department that has the funds to pay more, if you move to a lateral position, your salary will remain the same! This is not how other campuses do it.

job_title: Jack of All Traits in San Antonio, TX
pros: Healthcare benefits; that’s about it.
cons:
Primitive – Everything about the institution is primitive. Phrases like strategy and standard operating procedures are just buzz words that sound cool when said out loud in meetings. The reality is no one knows how to strategically plan; never mind how to execute the plan.

Fossilized – Executives, senior leaders and middle managers are incapable of adapting. To be clear, it is not because they don’t want to. The reasons basically boil down to as a “leadership” group they are mentally, physically, and emotionally incapable of changing to a modern business paradigm by putting aside their matriarchal or Napoleonic personalities or opinions. They lack the mental and intestinal fortitude to make difficult business decisions like saying “No”.

Radioactive – This institution is beyond toxic. As with any nuclear disaster there will be radioactive pollution requiring years to clear contaminants out (executives, personnel, inefficiencies, etc.) with known and unknown short and long-term effects. Known short term effects will manifest themselves quickly in the form of a mass exodus of key resources. Long-term effects will likely be financial in nature.

job_title: Medical Assistant in San Antonio, TX

cons:

“ either your a follower or management retaliates”

job_title: Associate Professor in San Antonio, TX

cons:

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in San Antonio, TX
pros: - great benefits and good pay
cons: still growing as a clinic

job_title: Program Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great mission and great benefits
cons: Need more flexibility of working from home

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Adequate PTO, sick leave, 12 holidays + 3 float.
Health insurance and life insurance for employee are paid by employer. 
Contribute to Teacher Retirement System (TRS) and Social Security.
Monthly longevity pay after 2 years and increases every 2 years thereafter.
Salaried (this can also be a con; given the low wages, the number of work hours can have you earning less than $20/hour).
cons:
No gender diversity - nearly 100% of PCs are female (perpetuates the gender-wage gap and "secretary" stigma).
Salaries remain stagnant and very low compared to other schools in the system and region, so turnover is high.
No parking options for hybrid employees.
Inconsistent working environments across institution; some departments/divisions are remote or hybrid, while others are 100% in-person, for no real discernable reason (role is 99% computer-based and most meetings are virtual).
No upward mobility; have to move out in order to move up.
Little support from institution on making the role into a management/leadership role, as it should be.
Management hierarchy is inconsistent - some PCs are supervised by a finance administrator, having little knowledge about what the role entails, while others are more appropriately supervised by their Program Directors.
Tuition reimbursement was eliminated in 2020 and has not been reinstated.
No incentives to attain higher education or job-related certifications (it appears that UTH does not value education).

review_title: Our pay should reflect our education level

review_title: No room for promotion, raises, or bonuses. Racist administration.
job_title: Program Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good comradery amongst co-workers (to vent frustrations). The benefits and pay here are *slightly* better than other colleges in SATX, but not worth the amount of stress.
cons:
There is no room for advancement. It is widely known that the school has no money (besides the medical school), so raises and bonuses are non-existent. I worked alongside people who'd been here for decades who had hardly ever received a raise, bonus, or promotion (even though their duties have increased tenfold). Even the cost-of-living adjustments are a joke.

Employees were blatantly told every year "do not expect a raise or promotion anytime soon" for five years straight before the pandemic. Offices are constantly being moved around, duties shifted between coworkers, and positions being erased due to the school's poor finances. Yet somehow each school (Health Professions, Nursing, Dental, Graduate, & Medical) can afford to pay at least 8 different associate deans at least $150,000 a year.

job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Wonderful institution that does everything it can for students!
cons: Lack of work life balance. Needs to find more ways to invest in employees to better retain the good employees.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Antonio, TX

job_title: Quality Improvement Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: UT offers various opportunities for professional growth and is a great place to start learning. The benefits are decent.
cons: Wages are not compatible to other large companies. There is a lot of work to be done in terms of daily responsibilities. often times employees find themselves staying after hours to complete a task. There is a culture here where it is frowned upon if you do not stay to finish your job but it’s also frowned upon if you go into overtime.

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: The health insurance offered by the university is probably the best benefits I will ever get from a company. However, my suspicion is that the university mandates this because they're not the ones paying for our benefits; the PIs are.
cons: Where do I even start? There is very little room for growth. Promotion is based on years of work and if you have the proper degree, but not based on the experience itself. So if you're a hard worker, you will end up doing senior level work without the pay or title. Also, promotion is not automatic based on performance reviews. You have to ask for it. I've known people from other departments who will not get a promotion even if they qualify, they will promote someone else less deserving because the deciding person or committee likes the latter better. When I was offered a promotion and raise, there was pushback from the HR department on how much I could get paid. Even though my boss was the one that was paying me, HR department wanted that person to pay me less (not that the offer is anywhere near industry standards). I thought HR was there to protect employees? The pay is barely living wage, and 1-2% cost of living raise that you MIGHT get is a joke. There is no incentive to work harder so what end up happening is that the hard workers get more work and the lazy workers get less work and get away with it. This place is fine if you're fresh out of college and needing training or experience, but anyone who knows their worth will not stay here long term.

pros: Great benefits for single person, great schedule and holidays are paid off. They offer separate sick leave and personal time off which not a lot of companies I’ve worked at do. Very routine, lots of changes in systems but once you get the hang out of it is very mellow. Not a lot of stress or work that follows you home.
cons: The benefits offered for dependents can get pretty hefty in deductions along with the mandatory TRS contributions you have to participate in. Also, have to pay for parking and won’t find much in the non-reserved spots even though it’s 30+ a month.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in San Antonio, TX

job_title: New Grad Nurse in Plano, TX

job_title: Administrative Assistant Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Salaried, was able to adjust my schedule as needed to arrive early or stay late.  Reserved parking even though I was on a wait list for a year.  Good benefits as long as you are single.
cons: You get paid once a month.  No chances of moving to another department or promotion.  The higher ups already have people in mind for the position and only list it because they have to.  Don't expect to get paid even with a Master's degree.  I have a Master's and was making $29,000 while those with higher titles made double or triple what I was making without the qualifications.   I got bypassed for a promotion when I knew all of the programs, but it went to someone else with no experience but had a Master's and still made way more money than I did.  If you have a family, expect no paycheck because of paying for benefits.  No tuition reimbursement or waivers of any kind for continued education.  Pay out of your paycheck to park on campus.  Upper Management is a joke.

job_title: PhD Candidate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Diversity! Great, innovative research at UTHSCSA. There is a wide range of projects you can be a part of and it is pretty easy to find a department with a project you're interested in. There are many opportunities to present your research. Great grant writing assistance and career development opportunities. Although departments are generally disorganized, the personnel and secretaries who have been here for years are very helpful and great cheerleaders for the students. Find the right PI/lab that is invested in your future success and you'll have a wonderful experience and awesome training!
cons: Multiple graduate students leave/pushed out of the program for various reasons. General complaints I've heard include lack of funding, lack of supportive mentor, research integrity of another lab member, etc. There are great inconsistencies between departments for length of the IBMS program. Although there is wonderful encouragement and support by dean's office, there is little support or encouragement from department chairs if a student is in search of a lab. No vacations are ever allowed for graduate students - not a PI rule, but a university rule.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good coworkers.  Some opportunities for training.  Good but not great pay though health insurance, retirement plan, days off are very good.
cons: I've been here about 15 years.  Over those years I've had many managers that scream and lose there temper frequently.  My current manager is no exception.  Acts like a bully and shows no respect to the people working with him.  Problem is once you're hired there is no interaction ever again with HR.  You don't know who to contact if you do email or call they act like you're bothering them.  Always take the side of supervisor/manager.  Managers now know they can get away with any treatment of employees they like.  My manager even openly makes comments about my age (I'm the oldest in the department) in front of everyone in meetings.  I'm sure not all departments have hostile working environments but I've been in two now and I hear it from several other people who are shocked at the anger they see their manager display in the workplace.

job_title: Faculty Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Position is Monday through Friday and no call
Decent vacation and holiday time
cons:
No tuition assistant, or career advancement 
No regular system wide advanced practice nurse/mid-level providers meetings
No discussion at the time of hire you are held to RVU productivity and the expectations are department based so no consistency across the organization.  One department APN get a 6 % salary increase and your department 0%. Also patient population is high with Carelink, Medicaid who do not value healthcare and keeping their appointments which results in a high no show rate and therefore effects your RVU productivity.  Working in the clinics with RVU productivity has made if feel like working in a blue collar factory.
No cost of living raises across the UT system since 2008 and no merit raises.
Same salary since 2009 and yet there has been a 10% cost of living increase
Low starting salary compare to private sector in the same field

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Bernardino, CA
pros: A nice environment with great colleagues. It's the only job where you can have a 100% office job but you'll still walk around and have many environments in your day to day. Depending on your dept you can have a wonderful/supportive team. There is tuition assistance but you have to apply each semester and it's not guaranteed.
cons: The benefits are lackluster. Single person gets medical employer sponsored but not dental or vision. Medical is fine. Doesn't cover infertility treatments. No domestic partner benefits. Not great for same-sex couples. Parking is expensive and mandatory for employees. Salaries are pretty low and even the "cost of living" raise doesn't keep up with inflation so you earn less and less each year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: There are many amazing scientists, researchers and professors here who are wonderful mentors and innovative thinkers. Fantastic laboratory facilities.
cons: This university lacks vision for the future of its medical students and the importance of medical research. Unfortunately, politics have taken over and many excellent professors and researchers are leaving. The university is being mismanagement by a bloated administration. They do not spend any effort on retaining their best employees. Salaries are being cut throughout the institute, people are being laid-off, and the researchers are getting hit the hardest. Moral is at an all-time low.

job_title: Medical Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Providers/Doctors were great. They took the time into teaching/educating you. 
Free employee medical insurance
TRS 
Great clinic hours 
Closed on weekends
cons:
Paid once a month
Pay for parking
Low merit increases
No room for growth
Experience or going out of your way means nothing
Payroll runs behind on monthly statements when you try to request refund from TRS

review_title: Manager, Application Systems Programming and Analysis
job_title: Manager in North Atlanta, GA
pros: Consistency in compensation, salaries tend lower than market, but benefits are good and tend to be stable. Work to support important work in education of health care professionals, and valuable research in science and health.
cons: Inconsistent management and leadership across the institution. Clinical activity has become the tail wagging the dog since grant funding is down, state budgets are down, and clinical revenue has increased.

review_title: Great Place to get Lab Experience and Learn
job_title: Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: I worked in the Microbiology Department under Dr. David Kadosh. I was able to gain a lot of lab experience as well as attend seminars, meet seminar speakers, make a poster, make lab meeting presentations, and mentor an undergraduate student. Because my plan was to enter graduate school, this job was a perfect segway for me to learn new things as well as meet different people in the field.
cons: Because it is an entry level position, the pay is pretty low. I was lucky because I was able to live with my parents, but living by yourself on the salary you are given would be tough.

job_title: Administrative in Reno, NV
pros: Great pay. Non-micromanagement style. Insurance is higher than other places but better coverage. Mgmt welcomes your ideas and encourages career development. Up to date with the latest and greatest software. Resources are easily made available which makes it pleasant to work.
cons: Pay is once a month. 2% merit increase vs the 3% norm. Parking is not free. It seems as some of the senior executives do not like communicating with lower staff for some reason - as if titles are more important than answering crucial emails that relate to the operations of the dept.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Antonio, TX
pros: I love the research. The facilities are top-notch and there are a lot of experts in the field of Aging and Cancer Research.
cons: They really low-ball salaries for postdoctoral fellows here. There is no Postdoc Policy in place and PIs are able to pay below the NIH minimum. Raises are definitely not regular, and there needs to be more oversight to regulate this unfairness. International students are especially taken advantage of.

review_title: used to be a good place to work
job_title: Professor Tenured in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good colleagues who are trying to make a difference
cons: I have worked here for 11 years and it has been going down hill for the last six.  Moral is at an all-time low and management is destroying the place.  People who can leave are jumping ship.  There have been wide-spread decreases in salaries as well as staff.

job_title: Academic Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Company pays for health insurance.  You earn vacation, sick, and personal time.. Interesting place to work if you are interested in learning more about medicine, healthcare.
cons: Paid on first working day of the month.  If the first day of the month is a weekend day or holiday, you will have to wait to be paid.  Limited growth and salary opportunities.  Non-faculty employees have low moral overall.   Very bureaucratic.

review_title: UTHSCSA is a great place to work!
job_title: Clinical Manager in Annapolis Junction, MD
pros: Provider really care about their patients and their staffs and there is potential for management staffs to have longevity with this organization.  The majority of staffs are committed.
cons: The company offers very limited opportunities for employees to earn incentives due to strict state limitations and rules.

review_title: Its good but not much career opportunities
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in San Antonio, TX
pros: The lab I worked was good. I could learn a lot and got good publications
cons: I am not generalizing here. Lab to lab difference will be there based on PI. Even if we work for 20 hrs a day there is no appreciation and not good place for career advancement. No promotions at all. Because of this its easy to loose interest in science.

review_title: Great place to work until our Director passed away
job_title: Radiology in San Antonio, TX
pros: Allowed to multi-task and be a 'team leader'', wearing many hats. Highly respected by colleagues and team members, benefits were great.
cons: When a new director took over, everything went downhill.Promises of advancement were never kept, despite excellent job performance and leadership skills. I was even mistaken by an othro doc as the supervisor. When the Doctor advised the actual Director of his concern, the new Director confided in me for a solution! However, I left with respect and professionalism.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in San Antonio, TX
pros: Paid Insurance benefits, location location location and in the Medical Center, room for advancement, vacation and sick leave benefits, and retirement.
cons: Some of the downsides is you have to pay for parking just to park your car their to work and you don't get paid a very good amount to live on.

review_title: Very few growth opportunities and lack of equal divison of work load
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Full medical benefits covered for the employee. Vacation, sick and personal time are all accumulated over time and available to use after 6 months of employment.
cons: The upper management are very narrow minded and do not fully get to know their employees. I have seen it  happen in different departments where dedicated workers look for new opportunities because they are rewarded with more work instead of growth opportunities.  You are also required to pay for parking.

job_title: Research Area Specialist Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: I worked in the Psychiatry Department at UTHSCSA, and it was an amazing experience. Specifically, I worked for the STRONG STAR research consortium in the Division of Behavioral Medicine and there is nothing wrong that I could say about that organization. Their passion for quality research and helping patients is remarkable.
cons: The only downside to working for UTHSCSA is the pay.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: The medical school is a great employer with great benefits.
cons: The management is managed well and it has a systemic downfall from there. Of course that should be judge from dept. to dept. I have never received a merit raise in 8 years and I have received 2 cost of living increases in that same time.

review_title: Excellent research experience, could improve networking capabilities
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Excellent research university with faculty willing to collaborate; great college town, perfect size and it supports the university like few others.
cons: More difficult than other universities of similar caliber to network with professionals/companies; of course this depends on the field, but Austin is a bit of an oasis.

job_title: Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great location, university management acknowledges that they don't always communicate well and seem to want to make improvements, making improvements to the buildings
cons: There is a distinct lack of respect from the executive level in a school. There is also a glaring lack of communication.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: The UT Health Science Center at San Antonio is a great place to work with wonderful benefits, they treat their employees very well
cons: The only downside is that employees are forced to pay for (somewhat expensive) parking passes, and the parking spots are far away from a lot of the buildings

review_title: If bureaucracy does not bother you - great place to work
job_title: Manager Laboratory in San Antonio, TX
pros: People are very nice and helpful. Within their own realm people are very likely to go out of their way to try and help you.
cons: It is a state entity, as such it has all the downsides of working for the state. The level of bureaucracy is stifling at times. It makes me wonder how anything progressive ever gets done here.

job_title: Accounting Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: It's a great entry-level position to start your career in. The salary and benefits are good.  In my department, we have great manager who care for you and your career development.
cons: At times, there's just too much work for you to realistically complete by yourself. Overtime is a must during the busy month but since it's a salary position you won't get extra money.

review_title: Management ruined a great place to work
job_title: Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Nice people, great town, good facilities as a state university there is investment by the state although it is decreasing.  Research is an emphasis
cons: Terrible moral, new management instituted draconian policies that add stress and worry to the faculty and staff.  Unlikely to change any time soon

job_title: Associate Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Collegial peers.  Growth culture.  State benefits.  Regional recognition.
cons:
As with many institutions, administration is shifting from Faculty control to MBAs.
State institutions tend to be slow in adopting new policy, processes.  Administrative burden higher then non-state options.

job_title: Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Great environment, nice people, challenging problems, flexible scheduling, great opportunities to network and reach out to during recruitment process.
cons: There were not that many cons. It was difficult to balance school with the projects given at times because certain weeks would be too strenuous while other weeks were much quieter.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: flexible work hours (depending on your job)
cons: benefits worse than nearby private sector, few opportunities for staff advancement, poor compensation increases for staff (regardless of outstanding yearly reviews), faculty treat staff poorly, lack of decent on-site cafeterias

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in San Antonio, TX
pros: Many dedicated faculty have outstanding research programs. Many post-docs find positions on staff.
cons: Everything is being swept into the medical school, which is run by people who know nothing about research. Many excellent research faculty are leaving. Still a good place for a post-doc if you get a good mentor, but I wouldn't advise sticking around.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Had opportunity and flexibility to develop my own research ideas as an independent investigator.
Have sufficient investment in equipment to support research.
Have excellent benefits.
cons: As a research faculty, almost 100% of salary has to come from my own grants. Not much support from the department or university.

job_title: Distance Educator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Lots of smart, educated people make for an eclectic educational environment. Best offices led by former military thanks to their many years of personnel development classes and experience.
cons: Painful commute traffic to and from thanks to own employees plus VA and other hospitals.  Sadly, those in management often have zero management/leadership training.

job_title: Academic Programs Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Diverse responsibilities that made job interesting and exciting. Worked with many nice people from various backgrounds.
cons: Constant turnovers and always understaffed. Low pay for work expected. No real room to move up without switching departments or jobs within the university.

job_title: Research Scientist in San Antonio, TX
pros: UHTSCSA concentrates on graduate and professional students and cutting edge research. The research environment is competitive and the Cancer Therapy Research Center (CTRC) at UT Health Science Center is an NCI designated cancer research center.
cons: The research environment can be both positive and also very competitive - both of which are good.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great benefits. If they see you have potential, they will try nurture it. Having a great immediate supervisor really helps.
cons: Interdepartamental issues, sometimes they are not all on the same page.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros:
I found working with major University  very rewarding .
Had the pleasure working in the epidemiology Dept.
The Medical Staff and Dept. were very untied .
loved working in this Dept.
cons: I really have nothing negative to say about this University.

review_title: Departmental IT jobs are better than working for IMS but still the pay level is low compared to corporate IT jobs.
job_title: Computer Repair Technician
pros: Good work/ life balance if you have a boss who believes the same.
cons: Lower than average pay and few opportunities for advancement.

review_title: Great ideas for improvement, not the best execution
job_title: Research Scientist in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-benefits are decent for a school system
-staff are attentive to concerns
cons: -good ideas for improving the academic programs or the research funding...but they don't pan out. Seems like the values are there but the logistics and nitty gritty details are where steering committees get mired

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great management, careful staffing and wonderful coworkers. Excellent health and retirement plans.
cons: Low pay-scales working for the state, frequent state-freezes on new hires and pay raises. Travel pay is too low, often lose money when traveling for work.

review_title: Great place to work and get career advice for the future.
job_title: Ph D Student in San Antonio, TX
pros: Every professor I met was eager to give great career advice. Easy to communicate with your superiors. Parking and gym are great.
cons: Some research facilities could use more upgrades, and the food service/cafeterias are terrible. Bring your own lunch.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great insurance benefits, vacation and sick leave policy
cons: Because you work for the state, in order to get a raise, you have to apply to another department that has an opening in a higher level position or different position.

job_title: Child and Adolescent Psychiatrist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great mentors, faculty and ancillary staff. Excellent teaching center for clinical and research experience. Wide array of patient diversity and acuity.
cons: Most trainers are from local schools. Has room for improvement in drawing attractive candidates from across the country. Some sites still on paper chart.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: The clinic I worked in was filled with some really great people and a tight-knit group that can be considered family. Health benefits were really good too
cons: The workload was not distributed evenly and more people definitely put in more work and effort than others

job_title: Administrative in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Working towards a good cause/helping better the community
Nice facilities
Benefits are excellent (PTO, medical, etc)
Friendly atmosphere
cons:
As with any government employer, you are paid slightly less than market. However, it is made up for with the benefits package.
Slow-moving democracy as in all higher ed

job_title: Executive Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Diverse responsibilities that made job interesting and exciting. Worked with many nice people from various backgrounds
cons: It is a big institution with many policies and procedures. Granted that is necessary but can be difficult at time.

job_title: Business Account Administrator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great State Benefits .. only great Retirement if you been there prior to 2003 or had 25 years service.
cons: Pay is based on State funds, which is low.. no raises but maybe an annual merit if no freeze on budget.   Only Faculty and Senior Management positions get the high salaries.

review_title: Good Medical Insurance and Benefits package
job_title: Nurse Practitioner in San Antonio, TX
pros: Diversity allows you to work with many people
cons: None to date at current employer

job_title: Laboratory Technician in San Antonio, TX
pros: Was able to get some hands on research experience as an undergrad.
cons: Not much room for advancement without post grad education.

review_title: Don't expect this is a typical academic place. Combination of bad things in industry and academia.
job_title: Assistant Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible working hours as in most academia. Can't think of something else.
cons: RO1 grant won't save you from being fired.

job_title: Dental Student in San Antonio, TX
pros: Communication, level of faculty, time spent investing in improving standard of education, facilities, at times transparency, I would attended again
cons: The university is large and at times you can feel like you get lost in the shuffle/unimportant, but again great institution.

job_title: Research Area Specialist Senior in San Antonio, TX
pros: Excellent benefits, >75% time employee gets free health (premiums paid) , Teachers Retirement System is a compulsory pension plan
cons:
Many or most jobs in research are grant funded and end after 3-5 years
Management depends on PI (usually doctors or scientists) without management training

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great people, great benefits, education is appreciated.
cons: State salaries, so they're lower than other companies. If you don't have a Ph.D. or M.D. then you're not going to get the higher salaries. Master's degrees get the coffee.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: Plenty of work to do for someone who already has experience
cons: Due to high work volume, this company does not have the time to train inexperienced employees.

job_title: Administrative Assistant-Senior in San Antonio, TX
pros: Wonderful interaction between lower and upper staff positions.  Outstanding health benefits.  Several onsite eateries.
cons: Automatic enrollment in TRS and employee paid parking lowered my expected income by 8% each month.

review_title: I am kind of satisfied with my current work at uthscsa.
job_title: in San Antonio, TX

more research freedom within the lab
supportive management

salary is lower than national average level
need more funding opportunities on basic science research from university

job_title: Project Coordinator in San Antonio, TX

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: I received great mentorship from the people I worked with in my lab.  I also had the opportunity to work on an independent research project.
cons: I don't really have any cons.

review_title: UTHSCSA has been a great place to work.
job_title: in San Antonio, TX
pros: Management listens to ideas and recommendations from employees.
cons: The salary is not comparable at times to the market.

review_title: Great place to do start career
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in San Antonio, TX
pros: Very hospitable environment and great place to start, especially as post graduate.
cons: Most what inherent to academic institutions: low speed paperwork, not so great compensated.

job_title: Research Area Specialist Senior in San Antonio, TX

cons: very hierarchical a bit of preference to friends, permissible to bullying , not much room for growth.

review_title: Great if you are a degree carrying male
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Excellent benefits.
Paid time off accrued monthly and quarterly.
cons:
Must pay for parking.
Sexist.
Snobby atmosphere.

job_title: Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Meaningful and valuable work contributing to the health of the public.
cons: Salary determined by grants earned and PI. No chance for movement or much pay increase. Difficult to sustain lifestyle longterm.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Supportive environment
-Small class sizes make for close-knit social support
cons:

-Not a lot of jobs in the immediate area for non-academic post-graduation work

review_title: UTHSCSA was a great place to work.
job_title: Compensation Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: Work/Life balance was encouraged and management was extremely family friendly.
cons: Since UTHSCSA is a state agency, salaries weren't as competitive as private industry.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great research environment.  Many areas of basic science and clinical research.  Lots of internal and external opportunities for collaboration.
cons: No obvious cons at the moment.

review_title: Depends on your PI but the overall company is good
job_title: Senior Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Depends on your PI but the overall company is good
cons: The pay is less than average again depending on lab

job_title: Research Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexible time off.  Generous vacation and paid sick time.  Good people to work with.  Great opportunities for learning.  Great wealth of knowledge.
cons: Infrequent raises, low salary, poor benefits, no room for advancement, experience not valued, exodus of good professors / researchers.  Generous vacation and paid sick time - if you are approved for time off.

job_title: Computer Support Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: almost no pressure to complete tasks
cons: some people with the same job title do a lot less work and more social media while at work.

job_title: Special Events Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Only pro is the benefits.
cons: The biggest con is management. Many “managers” lack any management skills. It’s demoralizing.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits are great and I look forward to putting in 5 years

review_title: Excellent Place to work, with good benefits....
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good staff, co-workers, compensation and benefits
cons: Hectic schedule in some labs, need to work some weekends

review_title: Perhaps a typical mid-tier public school residency program
job_title: Pathology Resident in San Antonio, TX
pros: Low cost of living at San Antonio.
